haricot 0.1.0

Modular binary domain

man_modular_binary_domain.Rd

Modular binary domain

Definition

A modular binary domain of a given dimension is defined as the ordered set of all possible combinations of modular binary number values in that dimension.
The modular binary domain (i.e. not mentioning a particular dimension) is defined as the super set of all modular binary domains in all possible dimensions.

Code implementation

This concept is implemented by the bdom R6 class.

Formal notation

A modular binary domain of dimension \(d\) is noted:\(\mathbb{B}_{d}\).

Samples

  • \(\mathbb{B} \): The modular binary domain superset.

  • \(\mathbb{B}_{1} = \left\{0,1\right\} \): The modular binary domain of dimension 1.

  • \(\mathbb{B}_{2} = \left\{00,10,01,11\right\} \): The modular binary domain of dimension 2.

  • \(\mathbb{B}_{3} = \left\{000,100,010,110,001,101,011,111\right\} \): The modular binary domain of dimension 3.

  • \(\mathbb{B}_{i} = \left\{00...i,10...i,...\right\} \): The modular binary domain of dimension i.

Visual Representations

Modular binary domains may be visually represented as vertical list of modular binary numbers.
The x axis (or columns) correspond to the respective bits of the module binary numbers: \(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}, ...\).
The y axis (or rows) correspond to the position of the modular binary number in the domain ordered by ascending order, that is equal to the integer value of that modular binary number.

See also
